Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Socially- and Geographically-Aware Modeling Framework for User Mobility in Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mobility models are an indispensable tool in the design, testing, and evaluation of wireless networks and their protocols. It is now widely recognized that mobility models should account for both geographical features of the region being studied as well as the social relations and interactions among users. This project aims to develop a unified yet flexible mobility modeling framework that combines both social and geography factors that influence how users move, and to develop formal statistical learning methods to calibrate mobility models using real mobility data. Additionally, an important deliverable of the project is to develop software tools that implement our models and can be used by researchers and practitioners to evaluate mobile systems and protocols.

This project is expected to have significant impact on the way network researchers and practitioners design, test, and evaluate mobile networks and their protocols. The project also has an important educational component: students working on this research are expected to develop a crosscutting research and academic and background. Research results from this project will be disseminated through project Web site, and technical papers published in conferences and journals. The mobility generation software tool will also be freely available through the project's Web site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project’s main goal was to understand how users move within a certain region (e.g., urban center, company/university campus) using their position (e.g., GPS) or network connectivity information (e.g., WiFi) to track movement. Based on this information, we developed mathematical models that describe how users move considering their spatial- (i.e., places they visit) and temporal (i.e., how long they visit) characteristics. Additionally, using user mobility records, we developed a technique that identifies user communities based on user common mobility features, namely their geographical preferences (locales they visit and spend time), movement speed, and time between consecutive movements. 
The project also motivated related research activities, notably techniques to guide deployment of IoT systems for outdoor applications and machine learning tools for network performance improvement. In the former, we focused on camera IoT camera deployments and developed algorithms that determine positions for camera IoT nodes such as to maximize the overall coverage of the target region, i.e., maximize the area that is visible by the camera IoT network. The latter research activity proposes simple, yet effective machine learning techniques that can automatically adjust network protocols (e.g., WiFi) based on current conditions (e.g., congestion) in order to improve their performance.


Intellectual Merit: The mobility models developed in this work are important for a number of reasons: they provide realistic movement patterns that can be used to evaluate networks and their protocols under real world mobility scenarios. They also motivated our follow-on work on user community identification which in turn can be used in the context of so-called Disruption-Tolerant Networks (DTNs) which are networks prone to arbitrarily frequent and long-lived disruptions in connectivity. In such networks, which typically operate in extreme environments (e.g., emergency response, disaster rescue, law enforcement), network nodes themselves are forwarders of traffic and can use user community information when deciding which relay node to forward a message in order to improve the chances that the message is delivered to its ultimate destination. Additionally, user community information can be used in other disciplines such as urban planning (e.g., Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), urban service deployment and placement, etc). Finally, our work on machine learning algorithms for network performance improvement yielded promising results which confirm that a simple ML technique can achieve significant performance gains.

Broader Impact: We argue that the work developed under this project has the potential for significant societal impact by helping to enable IoT applications, providing more realistic environments in which to test and evaluate mobile networks and their protocols as well as techniques to manage network performance by automatically adapting to current conditions. Additionally, as previously noted, our work can also benefit “smart city” planning, including ITS.
